verses.text: When the seventh month arrived, and the Israelites were in their cities, the people gathered together as one man in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The unity of the returned exiles in gathering for worship anticipates the ideal of perfect communion in faith. The seventh month is linked to major feasts, such as the Feast of Tabernacles (Lev. 23:34).

verses.text: Then Jeshua son of Jozadak and his fellow priests arose, and Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel and his associates, and they built the altar of the God of Israel to offer burnt offerings on it, as it is written in the Law of Moses the man of God.
verses.comment: Restoring worship according to the Law shows the importance of tradition and faithful obedience. Their actions are grounded in Scripture, reflecting continuity with the past.

verses.text: They set the altar in its place, for fear was upon them because of the peoples of the lands. They offered burnt offerings to the LORD on it, both morning and evening.
verses.comment: Worship in the face of external threats shows faith conquers fear. The regular offerings echo the need for ongoing sacrifice and prayer.

verses.text: And they kept the Feast of Booths, as it is written, and offered the daily burnt offerings by number, according to the rule, each day's requirement.
verses.comment: Celebrating the feast according to Scripture emphasizes liturgical worship and following prescribed rites, important for forming a people of true worshipers.

verses.text: After this, they offered the regular burnt offering, those for the new moons, and for all the appointed sacred feasts of the LORD, as well as the freewill offerings everyone brought to the LORD.
verses.comment: The restoration of all sacrifices, not just required ones, shows a love that goes beyond mere obligation, hinting at the New Testament principle of offering oneself fully to God (Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: From the first day of the seventh month they began to offer burnt offerings to the LORD. But the foundation of the LORD’s temple had not yet been laid.
verses.comment: Sacrifices begin even before the temple is rebuilt, showing that true worship is possible even in imperfect circumstances when intention is present. This foreshadows the building up of a spiritual house (1 Pet. 2:5).

verses.text: They gave money to the masons and carpenters; and food, drink, and oil to the people of Sidon and Tyre to bring cedar trees from Lebanon to the sea, to Joppa, according to the permission given them by Cyrus king of Persia.
verses.comment: The use of Gentile resources for God’s house mirrors the providence of God and echoes Solomon's construction of the first temple. This unity between nations hints at the universal scope of God's salvation.

verses.text: In the second year after their arrival at the house of God in Jerusalem, in the second month, Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel, Jeshua son of Jozadak, and the rest of their brothers—the priests and Levites and all who had come to Jerusalem from the captivity—began the work. They appointed Levites, twenty years old and upward, to supervise the work on the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: The proper appointment of Levites and leadership emphasizes the importance of apostolic succession and order in the assembly of God's people.

verses.text: Then Jeshua with his sons and brothers, and Kadmiel and his sons, the sons of Judah together supervised those who worked on the house of God, along with the sons of Henadad and their sons and brothers, the Levites.
verses.comment: Levitical leadership, with emphasis on the family lineage, illustrates the enduring significance of priestly authority and succession. This is later fulfilled in Christ, the eternal high priest (Heb. 7:23–25).

verses.text: When the builders laid the foundation of the temple of the LORD, the priests, in their vestments, stood with trumpets, and the Levites, the sons of Asaph, with cymbals, to praise the LORD, according to the directions of David king of Israel.
verses.comment: The celebration with vestments, music, and ritual as commanded by King David shows the importance of tradition and liturgical worship. Rituals convey the people’s reverence for God's holiness.

verses.text: They sang responsively, giving thanks to the LORD, 'For he is good, for his steadfast love endures forever toward Israel.' And all the people shouted with a great shout when they praised the LORD because the foundation of the house of the LORD was laid.
verses.comment: Responsive chant in worship reflects the ancient liturgical traditions. The phrase 'his love endures forever' is a frequent refrain in the Psalms, pointing to God’s covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: But many of the priests and Levites and the heads of fathers’ houses, old men who had seen the first temple, wept with a loud voice when they saw the foundation of this temple being laid, though many shouted aloud for joy.
verses.comment: The mixture of weeping and joy reveals the tension between memory of the former glory and hope for renewal. This prefigures the sorrow at exile and the joy at restoration, fulfilled in Christ, who brings a new temple—his body (John 2:19–21).

verses.text: So the people could not distinguish the sound of the joyful shout from the sound of the people weeping, for the people shouted with a great shout, and the sound was heard far away.
verses.comment: The mingled shouts of joy and sorrow symbolize both remembrance and hope. The temple points to the true spiritual house God is building, ultimately completed in Christ and the assembly of believers.
